name: Mahakali
description:
Where time ends, she begins. 
Mahakali is a spellbinding Kuchipudi production that delves into the cosmic dance of kAALA (time) and its eternal cycle of creation, preservation, and destruction. Drawing from the mythological universe of the Devi Bhagavatam and Devisaptashati, it brings alive the moment when the universe trembles under the weight of unchecked greed and imbalance, and the divine feminine rises to restore order. Through powerful choreography rooted in classical hastabhinaya, evocative ragas, and richly layered soundscapes, Mahakali captures the goddess’s transformation from Shakti to the vast, all-consuming force of time itself. 
A performance where rhythm becomes ritual, movement becomes mythology, and every beat echoes the turning of time’s eternal wheel. 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: India’s Development Odyssey
description:
What happens when one-sixth of humanity undertakes the world’s most complex development experiment? 
In A Sixth of Humanity, renowned political scientist Devesh Kapur and former Chief Economic Adviser Arvind Subramanian unpack India’s audacious journey of nation-building and economic transformation. Blending democracy, socialism, and liberalization in an unprecedented way, India has charted a “precocious” path to development—one that defies conventional models and continues to reshape global geopolitics and economics. 
Through this conversation, the authors reflect on India’s unique development trajectory, the paradoxes that define it, and what it reveals about the future of large, diverse democracies. 
The discussion will be followed by a Q&A with the audience

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Krishna to Kaveri | ಕೃಷ್ಣೆಯಿಂದ ಕಾವೇರಿವರೆಗೆ
description:
Winding and binding, Karnataka’s great rivers have always been more than glorious waterways. From Krishna to Kaveri, our rivers are carriers of culture, stories, and transformation. As they flow across varied landscapes, they shape and are shaped by the people, traditions, and communities they touch. 
Krishna to Kaveri is a two-day celebration that draws from this natural rhythm, exploring how Karnataka’s cultural life is constantly moving, adapting, and renewing itself. From classical roots to contemporary reinterpretations, this festival offers a vibrant weekend that speaks to a new generation. Expect immersive workshops, indulgent cuisines and impactful performances!  
Whether you’re a native Kannadiga or recently moved into Bangalore, this festival is for anyone who wants to connect more deeply with the cultural spirit of the region. Not as outsiders looking in, but as participants in a living, flowing cultural journey. 
Let the rivers lead. Let culture move. Let Karnataka unfold. 
ಬಳಸುತ್ತಾ ಬೆಸೆಯುತ್ತಾ ಬೆಳೆಸುತ್ತಾ ಸಾಗುವ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ನದಿಗಳು ವೈಭವದ ಜಲಹರಿವುಗಳು ಮಾತ್ರವಲ್ಲ. ಕೃಷ್ಣೆಯಿಂದ ಕಾವೇರಿವರೆಗೆ ವ್ಯಾಪಿಸಿರುವ ನದಿಗಳು ಸಂಸ್ಖೃತಿಯ, ಕಥೆ-ಪುರಾಣಗಳ, ಪರಿವರ್ತನೆಯ ಚಲನಶೀಲ ವಾಹಕಗಳಾಗಿವೆ. ವೈವಿಧ್ಯಮಯ ಸುಂದರ ಭೂಪ್ರದೇಶಗಳ ನಡುವೆ ಮುನ್ನಡೆವ ಈ ನದಿಗಳು ಜನರನ್ನು, ಪರಂಪರೆಗಳನ್ನು, ಸಮುದಾಯಗಳನ್ನು ರೂಪಿಸುತ್ತಾ, ಪರ್ಯಾಯವಾಗಿ ರೂಪುಗೊಳ್ಳುತ್ತಾ ಸಾಗಿವೆ. 
ಈ ಸ್ವಾಭಾವಿಕ ಹರಿವಿನ ಲಯದಿಂದ ಹೊಮ್ಮಿರುವ ಎರಡು ದಿನಗಳ ಉತ್ಸವವೆ ‘ಕೃಷ್ಣೆಯಿಂದ ಕಾವೇರಿವರೆಗೆ ʼ. ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಬದುಕಿನ ನಿರಂತರ ಚಲನೆಯ, ಹೊಂದಾಣಿಕೆಯ, ಪುನಶ್ಚೇತನದ ಶೋಧನೆ. ಈ ಉತ್ಸವವು ಅಭಿಜಾತ ಬೇರುಗಳಿಂದ ವರ್ತಮಾನದ ಮರುವ್ಯಾಖ್ಯಾನಗಳವರೆಗೆ ಹುರುಪಿನ ವಾರಾಂತ್ಯದಲ್ಲಿ ಹೊಸಪೀಳಿಗೆಗೆ ಒಳನೋಟಗಳನ್ನು ಒದಗಿಸಲಿದೆ. ತಲ್ಲೀನಗೊಳಿಸುವ ಕಾರ್ಯಾಗಾರಗಳು, ರುಚಿಕರ ಆಹಾರ, ಆಕರ್ಷಕ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಕಾರ್ಯಕ್ರಮಗಳನ್ನು ಈ ಹಬ್ಬದಲ್ಲಿ ನಿರೀಕ್ಷಿಸಬಹುದು. 
ನೀವು ಮೂಲ ಕನ್ನಡಿಗರಾಗಿರಿ ಅಥವಾ ಇತ್ತೀಚೆಗಷ್ಟೆ ಹೊರಗಿನಿಂದ ಬೆಂಗಳೂರಿಗೆ ಬಂದಿರುವವರೇ ಆಗಿರಿ. ಈ ನೆಲದ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಚೇತನದೊಂದಿಗೆ ಆಳವಾಗಿ ಬೆರೆಯುವ ಅವಕಾಶವನ್ನು ಈ ಹಬ್ಬ ನಿಮಗೆ ಒದಗಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಇಲ್ಲಿನ ಕಾರ್ಯಕ್ರಮಗಳನ್ನು ನೀವು ಹೊರಗಿನವರಾಗಿ ನಿಂತು ನೋಡುವ ಪ್ರೇಕ್ಷಕರಾಗದೆ ಒಂದು ಜೀವಂತ, ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಯಾನದ ಭಾಗವಾಗಲು ಬನ್ನಿರಿ. 
ಮುನ್ನಡೆಸಲಿ ನದಿಗಳು. ಪ್ರವಹಿಸಲಿ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿ. ಗೋಚರವಾಗಲಿ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ಸಿರಿ ವೈಭವ! 
Day 2 Schedule: 
7:30 AM – 9:00 AM: Yoga in Karnataka: Concepts and Traditions | ಕನಾ೯ಟಕದಲ್ಲಿ ಯೋಗದ ಪರಿಕಲ್ಪನೆ
Exploring the Essence of Yoga in Karnataka  | ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದಲ್ಲಿ ಯೋಗದ ಮೂಲತತ್ವದ ಅನ್ವೇಷಣೆ
Terrace
Medha Bhaskar takes us on a reflective journey into the spirit of yoga as practiced, preserved, and passed on as a living continuum within Karnataka. Beginning with a 45-minute experiential practice of asanas drawn from classical traditions, pranayama, and a short meditation, this session aims to embody the pursuit of balance between the worldly and the transcendent, the individual and the universal. A 30 minute discussion will follow, tracing the evolution of yoga in Karnataka across three broad periods: its ancient roots in Shaiva and Jain ascetic lineages, the medieval flowering of practice and philosophy, and the modern renaissance led by teachers and scholars from Mysore, Bangalore, and beyond. Yoga is both a cultural and contemplative inheritance — a practice through which Karnataka’s intellectual, artistic, and spiritual imagination continues to express itself. The session will close with a Q&A. 
10:00 AM – 11:30 AM: Songs from the Banks of Krishna and Kaveri | ಕೃಷ್ಣಾ ಮತ್ತು ಕಾವೇರಿ ನದಿ ತೀರದ ಹಾಡುಗಳು
Melodies of the River Saints | ನದಿ ಸಂತರ ನಾದಗಳು
Amphitheatre
Step into the musical world of Karnataka’s rivers, where devotion flows through melody. Chandana Bala Kalyan presents compositions of Saint poets who lived along the Krishna and Kaveri rivers and their tributaries, bringing alive the spiritual voices of centuries past. The evening traces the Abhanga of the Varkaris celebrating Panduranga on the Bhima River, journeys to the Haridasa Sahitya along the Tunga-Bhadra, and celebrates Kodava songs at Talakaveri in Kodagu. It concludes with selections from Mysore composers along the banks of the Kaveri. Accompanied by Satyajit Sanju on harmonium and Adarsh Shenoy on tabla, the performance weaves devotion, rhythm, and story into an immersive experience.
 
11:00 AM – 12:30 PM: The Missing Rocks of Hampi | ಹಂಪೆಯ ಕಾಣೆಯಾದ ಕಲ್ಲುಗಳು
History, mystery, and storytelling for young explorers. | ಯುವ ಸಾಹಸಿಗಳಿಗೆ ಇತಿಹಾಸ, ನಿಗೂಢ ಮತ್ತು ಕಥಾ ಹಂದರಗಳು.
Library
What made Hampi one of the most awe-inspiring cities of its time? The Missing Rocks of Hampi uncovers the secret through two thrilling stories: one of Devyani, Sarang, and Nakul, the Seekers from Bengaluru, and another of Shubha, a young dreamer in the Vijayanagara empire. As mysteries unfold along the Tungabhadra, children explore ancient water systems, culture, and clever engineering. The session includes fun, hands-on activities (yes, even acting like langurs!) that make history come alive. This Sunday, Mala Kumar leads an exploration of Hampi: where every rock has a secret to tell! 
11:30 AM – 1:00 PM: A New Dawn for Kannada Cinema: The Transformations of 1974–75 | ಕನ್ನಡ ಚಿತ್ರರಂಗದ ಪರ್ವಕಾಲ: 1974-75ರ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಗಳು 
A cinematic journey through five decades of prominent Kannada classics, brought alive with songs, visuals, and voices of beloved stars. | ಕನ್ನಡ ಚಿತ್ರರಂಗದ ಐದು ದಶಕಗಳ ಸುವರ್ಣಯಾನವನ್ನು ಮೆಲುಕು ಹಾಕುತ್ತಾ ಹಾಡು, ದೃಶ್ಯ ಮತ್ತು ನಮ್ಮ ನೆಚ್ಚಿನ ತಾರೆಗಳ ಧ್ವನಿಗಳ ಮೂಲಕ ಜೀವಂತಗೊಳಿಸುವ ಸಿನಿ ಪಯಣ.
Auditorium
The mid-1970s marked a turning point for Kannada cinema, with the shift of film production to Bengaluru and Mysuru, and the arrival of colour films shaping a distinctive identity. Art-house classics like Chomana Dudi and Hamsageethe brought national acclaim, while innovative film music enriched its aesthetic. Legends like Dr. Rajkumar and rising stars such as Vishnuvardhan defined this golden era. This session celebrates that remarkable journey through iconic scenes, vintage posters, and conversations with industry stalwarts, highlighting how these films not only shaped the industry but continue to inspire audiences across generations. 
2:00 PM – 3:30 PM: Digital Kannada Fonts | ಡಿಜಿಟಲ್ ಕನ್ನಡ ಅಕ್ಷರಶೈಲಿ
Bridging Traditional and Modern Communication | ಸಂಪ್ರದಾಯ ಮತ್ತು ಆಧುನಿಕ ಸಂವಹನವನ್ನು
Boardroom
Discover the art and evolution of Kannada script in this hands-on font design workshop with Manjunatha R. Participants will explore how the careful crafting of letters can preserve cultural identity while adapting to modern communication. The session blends tradition and creativity, showing how digital and hand-rendered forms of the script connect heritage with contemporary design. By the end, you’ll gain practical skills, a deeper appreciation for the script, and the confidence to create your own Kannada lettering! 
4:00 PM – 5:30 PM: Ilidu Baa Taaye | ಇಳಿದು ಬಾ ತಾಯೆ
A Journey Through Emotion and Melody | ಭಾವ ಮತ್ತು ಮಧುರಗಾನದ ಪಯಣ
Auditorium
Step into the lyrical journey of Bhaavageete where poetry finds its voice in melody. This 90-minute concert celebrates Sugama Sangeetha, Karnataka’s distinctive light music tradition that seamlessly blends classical and folk strains to amplify emotions, evoke devotion and inspire love for nature. Experience the timeless verses of literary greats such as Bendre, Kuvempu, Gopalakrishna Adiga, G.P. Rajaratnam, Dr. G.S. Shivarudrappa and Dr. H.S. Venkateshamurthy brought alive through the evocative compositions of Balappa Hukkeri, Padmacharan, H.R. Leelavathi, Mysore Ananthaswamy, Dr. C. Ashwath, and Raju Ananthaswamy. An evening where words and music entwine to stir the heart and mind!
 
4:00 PM – 5:30 PM: Chittara Folk Art for Kids | ಚಿತ್ತಾರ – ಮಕ್ಕಳಿಗಾಗಿ ಜಾನಪದ ಕಲೆ
From mud walls to little hands, Chittara comes alive! | ಮಣ್ಣಿನ ಗೋಡೆಗಳಿಂದ ಹಸುಳೆಗಳ ಕೈಗಳವರೆಗೂ, ಚಿತ್ತಾರ ಮತ್ತೆ ಜೀವಂತವಾಗುತ್ತದೆ!
Library
Chittara is a traditional mural art form of the Deevaru community from the Shimoga district of Karnataka. In this playful, hands-on workshop, children will discover how simple lines, patterns, and natural colours come together to tell stories of everyday life. They’ll learn about the symbolism and eco-friendly materials behind this beautiful tradition and create their very own Chittara painting: a joyful keepsake of Karnataka’s living heritage!
 
5:00 PM – 6:30 PM: Digital Kannada Fonts | ಡಿಜಿಟಲ್ ಕನ್ನಡ ಅಕ್ಷರಶೈಲಿ
Bridging Traditional and Modern Communication | ಸಂಪ್ರದಾಯ ಮತ್ತು ಆಧುನಿಕ ಸಂವಹನ
Boardroom
Discover the art and evolution of Kannada script in this hands-on font design workshop with Manjunatha R. Participants will explore how the careful crafting of letters can preserve cultural identity while adapting to modern communication. The session blends tradition and creativity, showing how digital and hand-rendered forms of the script connect heritage with contemporary design. By the end, you’ll gain practical skills, a deeper appreciation for the script, and the confidence to create your own Kannada lettering!
 
5:30 PM – 7:00 PM: Folk Songs
Hall 1 
7:00 PM – 8:30 PM: Vasu Dixit Collective
Auditorium

Monuments from Across the State!
Ground Floor Foyer

Learn to Play Traditional Board Games with Family and Friends.
Ground Floor Foyer

Read. Revel. Rejoice.

Cataloguing Vachanas across the state.
Second Floor Foyer
 
Presented by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: अभद्र | Abhadra: Story of One, Struggles of Many
description:
The rich traditions of Bhojpur shine in a Bharatanatyam narrative like no other! 
Abhadra, the first-ever Bharatanatyam production in the Bhojpuri language, tells a story that resonates far beyond its region. Through the elegance of classical dance, it explores the fragility of cultural heritage in the face of poverty, displacement, and migration. 
The performance traces the journey of communities whose language, traditions, and very existence are often overlooked or challenged. At the same time, it celebrates the vibrancy, resilience, and spirit of Bhojpuri culture—its music, stories, and lived experiences. Every gesture, rhythm, and expression reflects the delicate threads that weave identity and memory. 
Abhadra invites audiences to witness the intertwining of art and life, showing how classical performance can illuminate contemporary social realities while preserving cultural richness. It is a reminder of that which can be lost and can endure, when traditions meet the challenges of modern life. 
Experience a story where heritage dances, struggles, and survives, leaving a lasting impression on both heart and mind! 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Drawn to Doodle
description:
Tired of rescuing your walls from your little artist? This one’s for you!  
SCRIBBLE is a playful celebration of messy creativity and fearless imagination! Inspired by the book of the same name, this hands-on session invites kids (and their grown-ups!) to splash colours, draw freely, and turn everyday spaces into canvases of imagination. It’s messy, marvellous, and full of laughter. Every line tells a story and every squiggle becomes art. 
Let loose this Sunday: no erasers, no rules, just pure joy! 
Around the World in 50 Sundays is a journey that begins, not with a ticket, but with opening a book. In a city like Bangalore where families are always in motion, the BIC Library hopes to offer stillness and a quiet, welcoming space for both parents and children where reading becomes a shared way of being and not a task. 
Every Sunday, we open our doors to invite you into a library that listens; building a rhythm of return, a habit of joy and a new community bound not just by books, but by the weekly ritual of reading together. 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: RumuRumuRumu..! | ರುಮುರುಮುರುಮು..!
description:
A symphony born from the heart of everyday life! 
Rumurumurumu is a bold artistic experiment emerging from Bevinahalli in Sira Seema; a village where life and art are inseparable. Conceived by actor, writer, and filmmaker Shraddha Raj, the play is the result of months spent living among local arai and nadaswaram artists, weaving their stories, struggles, and sounds into a collective performance. Continuing the Jangama team’s earlier explorations of community art, Rumurumurumu extends this cultural movement, celebrating the voices, rhythms, and creative spirit of Bevinahalli’s Jiguru troupe.

ಶಿರಾ ಸೀಮೆಯ ‘ಬೇವಿನಹಳ್ಳಿ’ಯ ಅಪ್ರತಿಮ ಅರೆ ಮತ್ತು ನಾದಸ್ವರದ ಕಲಾವಿದರು ತಮ್ಮ ಕಲೆ ಮತ್ತು ಬದುಕಿನ ಅನುಭವಗಳನ್ನು ಬೆಸೆದುಕೊಂಡು ಕಟ್ಟಿರುವ ವಿಶೇಷ ಪ್ರಯೋಗ. ಹೊಸ ತಲೆಮಾರಿನ ಅನನ್ಯ ನಟಿ, ಬರಹಗಾರ್ತಿ, ಸಿನಿಮಾ ನಿರ್ದೇಶಕಿ ‘ಶ್ರದ್ದಾ ರಾಜ್’ ಅವರು ತಿಂಗಳ ಕಾಲ ಬೇವಿನಹಳ್ಳಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಇದ್ದು ವಿಭಿನ್ನ ಪ್ರಕ್ರಿಯೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ಈ  ನಾಟಕವನ್ನು ಕಟ್ಟಿದ್ದಾರೆ.  
ತಳ ಸಮುದಾಯಗಳ ಕಲೆ ಮತ್ತು ಕಲಾವಿದರ ಜೊತೆಗಿನ ಒಡನಾಟವನ್ನು ಒಂದು ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಚಳುವಿಯೆಂದು ಭಾವಿಸಿ ಜಂಗಮ ತಂಡ ಹಿಂದೆ ‘ಕೇರಿ -ಹಾಡು’ ಪ್ರಯೋಗವನ್ನು ಮಾಡಿತ್ತು. ಚಂದ್ರಶೇಕರ್ ಅವರು ದಿಂಡಗೂರಿನ ‘ಸಾವಿತ್ರಿ ಬಾಫುಲೆ ಮಹಿಳಾ ಸ್ವಸಹಾಯ ತಂಡ’ಕ್ಕೆಅದನ್ನು ನಿರ್ದೇಶಿಸಿದ್ದರು. ಪ್ರಸ್ತುತ ಅರೆಯ ನಾದ ಮತ್ತು ಬದುಕಿನ ‘ ರುಮುರುಮುರುಮು’ ಜಂಗಮ ಭಾವಿಸುವ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಚಳುವಳಿಯ ಮುಂದುವರಿಕೆ. ಬೇವಿನಹಳ್ಳಿಯ ‘ ಜಿಗುರು ‘ ತಂಡ. 
In collaboration with:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Bengaluru Bus Stories
description:
Carrying the people and pulse of a city. 
Bengaluru Bus Stories is a conversation on how public transport weaves lives together by connecting neighbourhoods, opportunities, and communities across the city. Drawing from EQUIMOB, an international research collaboration between the Institute for Social and Economic Change, Utrecht University, Bangalore Bus Prayaanikara Vedike, and SAMVADA, the discussion explores how buses shape daily life, build connections, and remain vital to the city’s social fabric. 
Moderated by Dr. Ranjana Raghunathan of Vidyashilp University, the panel brings together researchers and activists reflecting on their work with commuters and policymakers, reimagining Bengaluru’s buses as true lifelines that are designed with care, inclusion, and dignity at the core. 
Please note: The session will be bilingual in English and Kannada.

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: European Treasures
description:
The international duo formed by Norwegian soprano Elizaveta Agrafenina and French pianist Dimitri Malignan, established in 2019 in Amsterdam, will present a subtly chosen programme of splendid songs and works by the most celebrated European composers, including some audience favourites, as well as hidden gems by forgotten artists that they have been researching and uncovering for many years, as highlighted by their two recent album releases, “Elegies and Echoes” and “Le diable dans la nuit”, which received great critical acclaim. 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Will Lakshmi Find Her Pakshi?
description:
Lakshmi the calf is looking for her perfect bird friend—but will any of them stay?  
Join us for a delightful reading of Lakshmi’s Little Bird, Sharanya Kunnath’s beautifully hand-painted picture book. Children will giggle, moo, and join Lakshmi on her sweet adventure of friendship and patience. After the story, make and decorate your very own postcard for a special friend—ready to be mailed with love! 
Around the World in 50 Sundays is a journey that begins, not with a ticket, but with opening a book. In a city like Bangalore where families are always in motion, the BIC Library hopes to offer stillness and a quiet, welcoming space for both parents and children where reading becomes a shared way of being and not a task. 
Every Sunday, we open our doors to invite you into a library that listens; building a rhythm of return, a habit of joy and a new community bound not just by books, but by the weekly ritual of reading together. 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Reinventing Purpose
description:
What does it take to trade success for significance? 
Reinventing Purpose: Transitioning from Corporate to Cause brings together professionals who have redefined their careers to create lasting impact. Anchored around Sumathy Krishnan’s book A Career Without an Expiry Date: Finding Work, Growth and Fulfilment in NGOs, the conversation explores what it means to move from profit to purpose; unlearning old definitions of success while finding new forms of meaning, challenge, and growth. 
Through candid reflections and lived experience, the panel examines how skills honed in the corporate world can thrive in spaces that demand empathy, adaptability, and conviction. For those seeking to renew their relationship with work, this dialogue offers fresh perspectives, enthusiastic encouragement, and poignant reminders that fulfillment need not end where ambition begins.

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Be a Neighbourhood Naturalist
description:
Please note: This session is for children accompanied by adults. It will include separate activities for adults and children and will culminate in a joint activity. 
Kids’ session | 11 am – 12:30 pm | Saturday, 25 Oct | Library 
Adults’ session | 11 am – 12:30 pm | Saturday, 25 Oct | Seminar Hall 
Ever watched a spider spin its web, or wondered what stories the frogs tell after the rain? 
The natural world is alive with secrets waiting to be discovered. Be a Neighbourhood Naturalist, a beautifully illustrated activity book, opens our eyes to the extraordinary lives unfolding right in our backyards: curious birds, clever ants, mysterious mushrooms, and even the tiny creatures that share our homes. 
In this interactive event, children (7+) will dive into a playful, craft-based workshop filled with experiments, art, and observation. Learning to explore nature through creativity and curiosity is not for children alone! Adults will join an engaging conversation on how to nurture a love for nature and science (in children and adults alike) through inquiry, exploration, and hands-on discovery. 
Created by ecologist Vena Kapoor, illustrator Labonie Roy, and nature communicator Suhel Quader, the book and the workshop celebrate the secret joys of the natural world. 
The art of seeing life, in all its wonder, can begin just beyond our doorstep!

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Travellers
description:
What happens when sound stretches across time, memory, and place? 
Award-winning sarod musician and composer Soumik Datta breathes life into Travellers: a sonic journey that blends the evocative voice of the sarod with ambient soundscapes, spoken word, and Indian classical roots. Layered with field recordings and immersive textures, the performance moves fluidly between moments of stillness and pulse, carrying audiences across the invisible borders that divide lands, people, and memories. Each note unfolds a story, inviting reflection, connection, and wonder. 
Part of Soumik’s Melodies in Slow Motion Tour, the performance reaches concert halls, homes, heritage sites, and schools, touching communities often unheard, and reminding us how music bridges distance and difference. 
An evening of sound that offers a rare chance to experience music in its fullest depth. 
Travellers is coproduced by Soumik Datta Arts, G5A In Residence & Arts Council England. 
In collaboration with: 
 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Melodies of the Kaveri
description:
Where there is a river, there is song. 
Melodies of the Kaveri is a musical journey along the sacred river’s winding course; an ode to the waters that have inspired poets, saints, and composers for centuries. From the soulful kritis of Tyagaraja and Muthuswami Dikshitar to the devotional verses of Sripadaraya, Kanakadasa, and Tamil composers, each piece flows into the next like a tributary of devotion and creativity. This rich confluence of musical traditions celebrate the Kaveri as both muse and mother: nurturing life, spirit, and song across generations. 
An evening where melody meets memory, carried gently on the rhythm of a timeless river. 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Krishna to Kaveri | ಕೃಷ್ಣೆಯಿಂದ ಕಾವೇರಿವರೆಗೆ
description:
Winding and binding, Karnataka’s great rivers have always been more than glorious waterways. From Krishna to Kaveri, our rivers are carriers of culture, stories, and transformation. As they flow across varied landscapes, they shape and are shaped by the people, traditions, and communities they touch. 
Krishna to Kaveri is a two-day celebration that draws from this natural rhythm, exploring how Karnataka’s cultural life is constantly moving, adapting, and renewing itself. From classical roots to contemporary reinterpretations, this festival offers a vibrant weekend that speaks to a new generation. Expect immersive workshops, indulgent cuisines and impactful performances!  
Whether you’re a native Kannadiga or recently moved into Bangalore, this festival is for anyone who wants to connect more deeply with the cultural spirit of the region. Not as outsiders looking in, but as participants in a living, flowing cultural journey. 
Let the rivers lead. Let culture move. Let Karnataka unfold. 
ಬಳಸುತ್ತಾ ಬೆಸೆಯುತ್ತಾ ಬೆಳೆಸುತ್ತಾ ಸಾಗುವ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ನದಿಗಳು ವೈಭವದ ಜಲಹರಿವುಗಳು ಮಾತ್ರವಲ್ಲ. ಕೃಷ್ಣೆಯಿಂದ ಕಾವೇರಿವರೆಗೆ ವ್ಯಾಪಿಸಿರುವ ನದಿಗಳು ಸಂಸ್ಖೃತಿಯ, ಕಥೆ-ಪುರಾಣಗಳ, ಪರಿವರ್ತನೆಯ ಚಲನಶೀಲ ವಾಹಕಗಳಾಗಿವೆ. ವೈವಿಧ್ಯಮಯ ಸುಂದರ ಭೂಪ್ರದೇಶಗಳ ನಡುವೆ ಮುನ್ನಡೆವ ಈ ನದಿಗಳು ಜನರನ್ನು, ಪರಂಪರೆಗಳನ್ನು, ಸಮುದಾಯಗಳನ್ನು ರೂಪಿಸುತ್ತಾ, ಪರ್ಯಾಯವಾಗಿ ರೂಪುಗೊಳ್ಳುತ್ತಾ ಸಾಗಿವೆ. 
ಈ ಸ್ವಾಭಾವಿಕ ಹರಿವಿನ ಲಯದಿಂದ ಹೊಮ್ಮಿರುವ ಎರಡು ದಿನಗಳ ಉತ್ಸವವೆ ‘ಕೃಷ್ಣೆಯಿಂದ ಕಾವೇರಿವರೆಗೆ ʼ. ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಬದುಕಿನ ನಿರಂತರ ಚಲನೆಯ, ಹೊಂದಾಣಿಕೆಯ, ಪುನಶ್ಚೇತನದ ಶೋಧನೆ. ಈ ಉತ್ಸವವು ಅಭಿಜಾತ ಬೇರುಗಳಿಂದ ವರ್ತಮಾನದ ಮರುವ್ಯಾಖ್ಯಾನಗಳವರೆಗೆ ಹುರುಪಿನ ವಾರಾಂತ್ಯದಲ್ಲಿ ಹೊಸಪೀಳಿಗೆಗೆ ಒಳನೋಟಗಳನ್ನು ಒದಗಿಸಲಿದೆ. ತಲ್ಲೀನಗೊಳಿಸುವ ಕಾರ್ಯಾಗಾರಗಳು, ರುಚಿಕರ ಆಹಾರ, ಆಕರ್ಷಕ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಕಾರ್ಯಕ್ರಮಗಳನ್ನು ಈ ಹಬ್ಬದಲ್ಲಿ ನಿರೀಕ್ಷಿಸಬಹುದು. 
ನೀವು ಮೂಲ ಕನ್ನಡಿಗರಾಗಿರಿ ಅಥವಾ ಇತ್ತೀಚೆಗಷ್ಟೆ ಹೊರಗಿನಿಂದ ಬೆಂಗಳೂರಿಗೆ ಬಂದಿರುವವರೇ ಆಗಿರಿ. ಈ ನೆಲದ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಚೇತನದೊಂದಿಗೆ ಆಳವಾಗಿ ಬೆರೆಯುವ ಅವಕಾಶವನ್ನು ಈ ಹಬ್ಬ ನಿಮಗೆ ಒದಗಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಇಲ್ಲಿನ ಕಾರ್ಯಕ್ರಮಗಳನ್ನು ನೀವು ಹೊರಗಿನವರಾಗಿ ನಿಂತು ನೋಡುವ ಪ್ರೇಕ್ಷಕರಾಗದೆ ಒಂದು ಜೀವಂತ, ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಯಾನದ ಭಾಗವಾಗಲು ಬನ್ನಿರಿ. 
ಮುನ್ನಡೆಸಲಿ ನದಿಗಳು. ಪ್ರವಹಿಸಲಿ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿ. ಗೋಚರವಾಗಲಿ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ಸಿರಿ ವೈಭವ! 
Day 1 Schedule: 
10:00 AM – 10:50 AM: Inauguration | ಉದ್ಘಾಟನೆ
Pooja Kunitha, Somana Kunitha, Flag Hoisting & the State Anthem | ಪೂಜಾ ಕುನಿಥಾ, ಸೋಮನಾ ಕುನಿಥಾ, ಧ್ವಜಾರೋಹಣ ಮತ್ತು ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರಗೀತೆ
Ground Floor Foyer
Experience the vibrant ritual dances of Hale Mysuru with Pooja Kunitha and Somana Kunitha, performed by K. B. Swamy and team. Rooted in Hassan, Tumakuru, Mandya, and Bangalore Rural, these centuries-old traditions reflect devotion and community life. Pooja Kunitha, performed by the Kuruba community, offers towering, decorated structures to Goddess Shakti, while Somana Kunitha, with striking masks and movements, invokes guardian deities to bless villages. Together, they carry the history, geography, and spirit of Hale Mysuru. This performance, in celebration of Karnataka Rajyotsava, honors the living cultural traditions that continue to shape the soul of the state. 
11:00 AM – 12:30 PM: Morning Melodies | ಮುಂಜನೇಯ ರಾಗಗಳು
A Hindustani Vocal Recital | ಹಿಂದೂಸ್ತಾನಿ ಗಾಯನ
Auditorium 
11:00 AM – 12:30 PM: The Great Story Hunt | ಬೃಹತ್ ಕಥೆಯ ಹುಡುಕಾಟ
Rivers, rulers, quilts, and queens — a treasure trail through Karnataka’s timeless scenes. | ನದಿಗಳು, ರಾಜ ಮಹಾರಾಜರು, ಹೊದಿಕೆಗಳು, ರಾಣಿಗಳು — ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ಸಮಯಾತೀತ  ದೃಶ್ಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಹೊನ್ನಿನ ಹಾದಿ.
Library
What travels without tickets, flies without wings, and takes you places while you sit and listen? A story!
Seema Karanth leads us into a world where riddles, rhythm, and laughter fuel adventure. This interactive storytelling session is filled with mysteries to solve, clues to chase, and characters to befriend. Children become part of the tale itself: playing, guessing, and imagining their way through adventure.
Perfect for curious young explorers and their families to listen, laugh, and journey together!
 
1:30 PM – 2:30 PM: Kannada Gottilla | ಕನ್ನಡ ಗೊತ್ತಿಲ್ಲ
Kannada 101: A Crash Course in Connection. | ಕನ್ನಡ ೧೦೧: ಸಂವಹನದ ತ್ವರಿತ ಪಾಠಕ್ರಮ.
Boardroom 
2:00 PM – 3:30 PM: Sutha Mutha Gotha? | ಸುತ್ತ ಮುತ್ತ ಗೊತ್ತಾ?
Quizzing All Things Karnataka and Kannada | ಕರ್ನಾಟಕ ಮತ್ತು ಕನ್ನಡದ ಎಲ್ಲ ವಿಷಯಗಳ ಕುರಿತ ಮನರಂಜನಾತ್ಮಕ ಪ್ರಶ್ನೋತ್ತರ ಸ್ಪರ್ಧೆ
Hall 1
A 90 minute journey full of questions on interesting facts and stories from our state. The quiz is for teams of up to two people. There will be a written prelims, followed by a final round for the top teams. 
Hosted by Thejaswi Udupa, this is bound to be a fun-filled afternoon!  
3:00 PM – 4:00 PM: An Afternoon of Magic | ಮಾಯಾಮಯ ಮಧ್ಯಾಹ್ನ
A Wonder-Full Show for All Ages | ಎಲ್ಲಾ ವಯಸ್ಸಿನವರಿಗೆ ಆಶ್ಚರ್ಯಭರಿತ ಪ್ರದರ್ಶನ
Library
Experience a world of laughter, mystery, and amazement with Bangalore’s beloved magical ensemble, Nakul Shenoy & Friends. This hour-long performance blends storytelling, comedy, mind-bending magic, and mesmerizing shadow play. Featuring the youthful energy of The Amazing iTwins and Prahlad Acharya’s spellbinding shadowgraphy from Speaking Shadows, the show enchants audiences of all ages. Whether discovering magic for the first time or a lifelong enthusiast, you’ll be transported to a realm where imagination rules and the impossible feels real—an unforgettable, joyous experience for the entire family. 
3:00 PM – 4:30 PM: Kannada Gottilla | ಕನ್ನಡ ಗೊತ್ತಿಲ್ಲ
Kannada 101: A Crash Course in Connection. | ಕನ್ನಡ ೧೦೧: ಸಂವಹನದ ತ್ವರಿತ ಪಾಠಕ್ರಮ.
Boardroom 
4:00 PM – 5:30 PM: Beeso Haada – Songs of Labour | ಬೀಸೋ ಹಾಡ – ಶ್ರಮಿಕರ ಗೀತೆಗಳು
Folk Songs from the Soil of North Karnataka | ಉತ್ತರ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ಗಂಡುನೆಲದಿಂದ ಹೊಮ್ಮಿದ ಜನಪದ ಗೀತೆಗಳು
Amphitheatre
Beeso Haada is the collective embodiment of oral musical traditions of labour. These songs collected from different women from across North Karnataka speak of labour of daily life, labour of gender and of caste. Collected and curated meticulously over the last two years, these songs taught by the hereditary practitioners from Kuruba and Golla community, speaks of daily struggles, aspirations, dreams, spirituality and resilience.
ಬೀಸೋ ಹಾಡ – ಕಾರ್ಮಿಕರ ಮೌಖಿಕ ಸಂಗೀತ ಸಂಪ್ರದಾಯಗಳ ಒಂದು ಸಾಮೂಹಿಕ ರೂಪವಾಗಿದೆ. ಉತ್ತರ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದ ವಿವಿಧ ಭಾಗಗಳ ಮಹಿಳೆಯರಿಂದ ಸಂಗ್ರಹಿಸಲಾದ ಈ ಹಾಡುಗಳು ದೈನಂದಿನ ಬದುಕಿನ ಬವಣೆ, ಲಿಂಗ ಮತ್ತು ಜಾತಿ ಸಂಬಂಧಿತ ಶ್ರಮದ ಕುರಿತದ್ದಾಗಿವೆ. ಕುರುಬ ಮತ್ತು ಗೊಲ್ಲ ಸಮುದಾಯಗಳ ಆಚರಣೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ನಿರತರಾದ ಜನ ತಲೆತಲಾಂತರಗಳಿಂದ ಈ ಹಾಡುಗಳನ್ನು ಕಲಿಸುತ್ತಾ ಬಂದಿದ್ದು, ಇವನ್ನು ಕಳೆದ ಎರಡು ವರ್ಷಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ನಿಖರವಾಗಿ ಸಂಗ್ರಹಿಸಿ ಶೇಖರಿಸಲಾಗಿದೆ. ಈ ಹಾಡುಗಳು ಜನರ ದಿನನಿತ್ಯದ ಹೋರಾಟಗಳು, ಆಕಾಂಕ್ಷೆಗಳು, ಕನಸುಗಳು, ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕತೆ ಮತ್ತು ಪುನಶ್ಚೇತರಿಕೆಯಂಥ ಅಂಶಗಳತ್ತ ಕೇಂದ್ರೀಕೃತವಾಗಿವೆ. 
5:30 PM – 6:30 PM: Prathibimba – #13, Srimata, Sadhanakeri, Dharwad | ಪ್ರತಿಬಿಂಬ – #13, ಶ್ರೀಮಾತ, ಸಾಧನಕೇರಿ, ಧಾರವಾಡ
A Multi-Media Tribute to Jnanpith Laureate Da. Ra. Bendre. | ಜ್ಞಾನಪೀಠ ಪ್ರಶಸ್ತಿ ವಿಜೇತ ಡಾ. ರಾ. ಬೇಂದ್ರೆ ಅವರ ಗೌರವಾರ್ಥ ಬಹು-ಸ್ವರೂಪದ ಪ್ರದರ್ಶನ.
Auditorium
This performance is a poetic mirror of a man, his art, and the timeless questions he left behind. Da. Ra. Bendre was a poet, philosopher, and pioneer of the Navodaya movement. He remains one of Kannada literature’s most luminous voices. Awarded the Jnanpith in 1973 for Naaku Tanti, his poetry reflected life as he lived it: intimate, questioning, and endlessly evolving. Prathibimba captures the essence of Bendre’s journey: his joys, struggles, and transformation from youth to old age, from words to numbers. Drawing from Tagore and Aurobindo, he wove together nationalism, spirituality, and humanism into a vision that still stirs the soul.  
7:30 PM – 9:00 PM: 100 years of Grooving! | ನೂರು ವರ್ಷಗಳ ಸಂಭ್ರಮ!
Time Travel through a Century of Bengaluru’s Beats | ತಾಳಮೇಳಗಳ ಮೂಲಕ ಬೆಂಗಳೂರಿನ ಕಳೆದ ನೂರು ವರ್ಷಗಳ ಕಾಲಯಾನ
Auditorium
Step into a soundscape where history has rhythm and every decade hums a new tune. GROOVE BLR takes you on a rollicking ride through 100 years of Bengaluru’s music: from the regal echoes of colonial brass bands and veena virtuosos to disco fever, bhavageethe’s lyrical grace, and the punch of Kannada rap. Narrated by a sharp, quick-witted Quizmaster armed with stories, surprises, and city trivia, this concert blends live performance, storytelling, and laughter in one irresistible mix. Expect clever musical mashups, playful audience interactions, and a few surprises in between. As melodies shift from Gayana Samaja’s grandeur to the pulsing pubs of Church Street, you’ll hear the city’s journey through change, chaos, and creativity. A musical celebration that proves one thing: Bengaluru doesn’t just make music, it becomes music. 
  
Across the Weekend: 
11:00 AM – 8:00 PM: Exploring Karnataka Exhibition
Monuments from Across the State!
Ground Floor Foyer 
11:00 AM – 8:00 PM: Aata Aadu Bengaluru by Kavade
Learn to Play Traditional Board Games with Family and Friends.
Ground Floor Foyer

Display of Traditional Arts by Modern Artists.
First Floor Foyer

Read. Revel. Rejoice. 
Hall 2 
11:00 AM – 8:00 PM: Wildlife Photography Exhibition by Arun Krishnaiah
Capturing the Biodiversity of Karnataka.
Gallery 
11:00 AM – 7:00 PM: Chasing Clues, Celebrating Culture
A Scavenger Hunt through Karnataka! 
Boardroom 
11:00 AM – 8:00 PM: Vachanas of Karnataka by Azim Premji University
Cataloguing Vachanas across the state.
Second Floor Foyer 
  
Presented by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: The Rasika
description:
What do you really see when a classical dancer takes the stage? 
Is it the beauty of the movement, the rhythm of the music, or the story unfolding before your eyes? This evening invites you to look closer, to discover the richness within Indian classical dance; the traditional repertoire, the interplay of melody and rhythm, the subtle gestures that carry meaning, and the role of texts that shape interpretation. 
Guided by Dr. Sahana Das, a seasoned choreographer and researcher, the session opens up the world of classical dance in ways that both newcomers and longtime rasikas can enjoy. Adding depth and texture are dancers Kirti Ramgopal and Meghna Das, who bring their own artistry in Bharatanatyam and Odissi to the conversation. 
Through reflection and performance, the evening gently unravels the intricacies of these timeless traditions, reminding us that dance is not just to be seen: it is to be experienced, understood, and felt!

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Responsible Use of Generative AI
description:
It can write, draw, and think with us, but can we truly trust it? 
Generative AI is transforming how we learn, create, and communicate, yet behind its brilliance lie complex questions of bias, privacy, and ethics. This talk delves into the unseen side of GenAI: its limitations, vulnerabilities, and the delicate balance between innovation and integrity. Drawing on insights from academia and industry, it explores how we can use these tools responsibly while preserving human judgment and accountability. 
The session will close with a Q&A: an invitation to think critically, act consciously, and shape a future balanced with technology and humanity.  
This lecture is a part of Azim Premji University’s Public Lecture Series. 
Presented by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Screening the Mind
description:
Cinema has immense power to shape societal narratives around mental health, meaningful, accurate portrayals are not yet mainstream. Last year at Manotsava 2024, a panel discussion explored how Indian cinema is beginning to move beyond stereotypes, shifting from sensationalism to more empathetic, everyday depictions that normalize therapy, emotional vulnerability, and recovery. Meaningful, intentional representation on the silver screen can encourage open conversations, challenge stigma, reshape public perception, and become a force for social change. 
As a lead-up to the next edition of Manotsava – RNP, NIMHANS & NCBS are putting together a film showcase that will explore mental health through contemporary Indian cinema, offering audiences a view into diverse psychological experiences and societal perspectives.  
The screening will feature 6 films including Shonali Bose’s Margarita with a Straw, which sensitively portrays disability and sexuality and Amol Palekar’s Dhoosar,exploring Alzheimer’s and caregiving. Visitors can also browse and buy books on mental health at Bookworm’s stall; and can touch and feel exhibits of the human brain, brought by the NIMHANS Brain Museum between 12 to 2 pm. Conversations at the film festival will be moderated by Nikhil Waiker, founder of The Parallel Cinema Club. 
Festival Schedule: 
11:00 am – 11:20 am: Khidki
16 mins | Hindi with English subtitles | Director: Anhad Mishra
Khidki tells the moving story of an elderly man whose closest bond is with the world outside his window. Alone in a city that has left him behind, he finds comfort in its everyday rhythms. But when he must leave the home—and the view—that has sustained him for years, he confronts a devastating question: can he survive without the only thing keeping him alive? 
11:20 am – 1:00 pm: Dhoosar
1 hr 40 min | Marathi with English subtitles | Director: Amol Palekar
Dhoosar traces the emotional journey of a daughter who returns home to find her mother battling Alzheimer’s. As the illness reshapes memory and identity, it also transforms the bonds of family, revealing the quiet struggles and shifting realities of those left to cope. 
2:30 pm – 2:50 pm: Invisible Chains
18 min | Kannada with English subtitles | Director: Maya Chandra
Invisible Chains is a documentary under the “Drug-Free Karnataka” (Nashe Mukta Karnataka) campaign—an initiative by the Karnataka State Police with MAYA Films and Manipal Foundation. Through first-person accounts, it portrays the impact of substance use on mental, physical, and emotional health. With insights from experts and legal voices, it highlights the challenges of recovery and the consequences of drug-related offenses, while calling for greater awareness and collective action. 
3:00 pm – 3:30 pm: Enso
30 min | Kannada with English subtitles | Director: Megha Havanje
Enso is the story of a father and daughter navigating the trauma of an unexpected loss, as they search for healing and a way forward together. 
3:45 pm – 4:30 pm: Swagatam
45 min | Hindi with English subtitles | Director: Sukriti Tyagi
Swagatam follows the lives of a young married couple in a small Maharashtrian town. When the husband, living with schizophrenia, wishes to attend his friend’s wedding, the film offers a sensitive look at his experience—moving beyond the usual stereotypes to portray the everyday realities of living with the condition. 
4:40 pm – 7:00 pm: Margarita with a Straw
2 hr 20 min | English & Hindi with English subtitles | Director: Shonali Bose
Margherita with a Straw tells the story of a young woman—romantic at heart and a quiet rebel—who navigates life in a wheelchair with unshaken spirit. Living with cerebral palsy, she sets out on a journey of sexual discovery that challenges her relationships and her sense of self. In the midst of these conflicts, she ultimately finds strength in the depth of her closest bonds.
